title: Cambridge-Style Grammar Gap-Fill (Use of English)
note: Options have been deliberately shuffled (non-sequential) and the correct answers across items are distributed to avoid predictable patterns.

sentences.text: The consultant _____ handled the merger is the one the board now relies on most.
The journalist _____ investigation exposed the scandal refused to reveal her sources.
That’s the conference centre _____ we first met the investors who later funded the project.
The candidate _____ the panel were most impressed by has just accepted the position.
It was the kind of risk _____ even experienced traders avoid when markets turn volatile.
Do you remember the moment _____ it dawned on you that you’d made the wrong assumption?
The proposal _____ you emailed last night still fails to address the budget shortfall.
I know someone _____ sister negotiated the contract you’re referring to.
This is the district _____ rents have doubled in less than a decade.
I finally spoke to the professor _____ recommended that I apply for the scholarship.
All visitors _____ sign in at reception before accessing the research wing.
You _____ disclose client data to anyone outside the team, even informally.
You _____ book in advance; walk-ins are accepted on most weekdays.
He _____ be the author; the style is completely different from his earlier work.
If you want your complaint taken seriously, you _____ provide evidence rather than speculation.
They _____ still be in the office; the lights are on, but that proves nothing.
You _____ leave now, if you like, but please let me know when you arrive.
We _____ address the issue now, before it escalates into something more serious.
She _____ be at home; her coat is here, but she often leaves it behind.
You _____ interrupt the speaker; questions are taken at the end.
I _____ she realises how serious the consequences could be.
There were _____ seats left, so we had to stand at the back.

_____ John who insisted we restart the entire process from scratch.
_____ is some uninterrupted time to think things through.
_____ is the truth, even if it’s uncomfortable to hear.
_____ annoys me is the way he dismisses other people’s ideas.
_____ was so blunt that everyone fell silent.
_____ raised the issue first was the intern, not the manager.
_____ is apologise before the situation deteriorates any further.
_____ in Paris that she finally decided to change careers.
_____ is some encouragement, not another lecture about responsibility.
_____ a holiday that I need, not an extra day at my desk.
There’s _____ that the policy has backfired.
It _____ that safety procedures have to be followed.
_____ you're exhausted after dealing with complaints all day.
_____ the revised deadline, we can be flexible if necessary.
_____ reliability, this model outperforms the previous one by a long way.
We _____ the long-term consequences before committing to the partnership.
_____, we agreed that walking away was the only sensible option.
_____, the changes have improved morale, even if a few issues remain.

We arrived late and, _____, the presentation had already started.
There isn’t _____ time left, so we’ll have to prioritise the essentials.
There aren’t _____ people who can explain the issue as clearly as she can.
We have _____ money to spare at the moment, so let’s avoid unnecessary purchases.
_____ people were willing to challenge the decision openly, which was telling.
We have _____ time, so we can at least discuss the basics before we go.
There are _____ points we still need to clarify, but nothing major.
_____ the candidates were asked the same questions to ensure fairness.
_____ student is expected to submit the assignment by Friday, without exception.
_____ options have drawbacks, which is why the decision isn’t straightforward.
